instruction:
As a TCFD expert, please address the following inquiries:

1. Outline the function of management in evaluating and addressing climate-related risks and prospects.
output:
Roles and responsibilities for climate-related risks and opportunities:

• Specific roles and responsibilities for the oversight of climate change have been delegated to management. These are defined within the 'Governance committees and steering groups with responsibility for climate-related issues' section. Climate-related agenda frequency and inputs are also set out for these bodies.

• Our company, led by the Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO), is responsible for creating and executing the sustainability strategy, including delivery against our net zero pathway.

• Responsibility for identifying and managing financial risks from climate change lies with our Group Chief Risk Officer (Group CRO) as the appropriate Senior Management Function (SMF) under the Senior Managers Regime (SMR).

• The Group CRO is supported by the Global Head, Enterprise Risk Management who has day-to-day oversight and central responsibility for our company's second line of defence against Climate Risk.

• The organisation structure associated with climate change has also been set out in the 'Governance of our Sustainability Agenda' chapter of our annual report. A description of the associated organisational structures and their monitoring of climate-related issues. Processes used to inform management:

• Our company is informed by several committees and forums, with climate-related information communicated via channels including our Group CRO and Climate Risk Information Reports.

instruction:
As an expert in the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, I will offer a comprehensive guide on how to efficiently assess and communicate climate-related risks and prospects for an organization. This discussion will focus on the significance of governance, strategic alignment, and risk management practices in this context.

To begin, let us address the climate-related risks and opportunities that the organization has recognized over the short, medium, and long term.

1. In the short term, what climate-related risks and opportunities have been identified?
2. How about the medium-term outlook? What climate-related risks and opportunities are anticipated?
3. Lastly, what are the climate-related risks and opportunities that the organization foresees in the long term?

By providing answers to these questions, the organization can demonstrate its understanding of the climate-related risks and opportunities that may impact its business and financial performance. This transparency is essential for investors, regulators, and other stakeholders seeking to evaluate the organization's resilience and adaptability in the face of climate-related challenges.
output:
Processed text:

Relevant time horizons: In our strategic business planning, we distinguish 'short-term' as less than two years, 'medium-term' as two to five years, and 'long-term' as beyond this. For climate scenario analysis, we can run 30-year scenarios for both Physical and Transition Risk. Some aspects of our Physical Risk scenario analysis may extend to 2100.

Methods used to identify material risks and opportunities: We employ a variety of tools and methodologies to evaluate Transition and Physical Climate Risk, which we apply to our clients, portfolios, and our own operations. These include scenario analysis, location-based hazard and risk scores, temperature alignment scores, and Munich Re's NATHAN tool (acute physical risk impact assessments). In addition, we engage with our corporate clients to understand their transition and physical risks, as well as their plans to prepare for climate change. In 2022, we continued to expand our comprehension of climate-related risks and significantly fortified our stress testing and scenario analysis capabilities for a range of management scenarios that are more probable.

Climate-related risks and opportunities recognized: We have assessed the impact of Climate Risk on our business using scenario analysis over a 30-year time horizon, which has allowed us to identify and mitigate climate risks that may materialize. Sustainability and climate change have evolved from being primarily risk-based initiatives to becoming a value driver. This presents us with an opportunity to leverage our market and industry knowledge to counsel our clients on their individual sustainability journeys. Sustainable finance represents an opportunity to both safeguard our existing business from Transition Risk and to fund our clients' transition from a high-carbon present to a low-carbon future. By supporting clients on their net zero journeys and providing further finance to clients as they adapt to be less carbon intensive and emitting over time, we help mitigate their, and our, Transition Risk. Our objective is to generate $1 billion in Sustainable Finance income by 2025 and to mobilize $300 billion of Sustainable Finance by 2030 as indicators of success. We do not fully disclose the impact on financial planning and performance (including proportions of income, costs, and balance sheet related to climate-related opportunities), detailed Climate Risk exposures for all sectors and geographies, or physical risk metrics. Data limitations, and our plans to address these, are discussed in greater detail in the report.

Significant concentrations of credit exposure to carbon-related assets: We have disclosed our exposures to high-carbon sectors, which includes the expected credit losses on these balances as well as the maturity profiles associated with them. Our exposure to high-carbon sectors comprises 14.4% of our loan balances. We aim to become net zero in our financed emissions by 2050, with interim 2030 targets for our highest emitting sectors. In 2022, we made progress towards this goal and set out to measure, manage, and reduce emissions starting with our most carbon-intensive sectors, in accordance with our net zero roadmap.

instruction:
To respond effectively to your TCFD-related query, please address the following inquiries:

1. Outline the influence of climate-related risks and prospects on the organization's operations, strategic direction, and financial forecasting.
output:
Impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on business areas:
Our company has measured and reduced our greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions since 2008 and have been actively targeting a reduction in our Scope 1 and 2 emissions towards a well-below two degrees Celsius scenario since 2018. We plan to optimize our office and branch network, continually maximizing efficiency while leveraging clean and renewable power where appropriate. In line with our commitment to the global corporate renewable initiative, RE100, we aim to meet our own challenging targets.

Suppliers:
Through our Supplier Charter, we encourage our suppliers to support and promote environmental protection and manage and mitigate environmental risks. In 2022, we launched a global project to define strategies to address emissions related to Scope 3 Category 1, 2, 4, and 6. Our internal targets cover reducing our emissions related to upstream transportation and distribution and business travel by 28% against 2019 levels over the next seven years. For purchased goods and services and capital goods categories, we plan to engage our suppliers (covering approximately 67% of spend) to set science-based targets in the next five years.

Products and services:
Our company has set targets to achieve $1 billion of Sustainable Finance income by 2025, to mobilize $300 billion of Sustainable Finance by 2030, and to launch and grow green mortgages in key markets across our footprint. In 2022, we made progress against these targets, reporting $0.5 billion in Sustainable Finance income, mobilizing $23.4 billion through our Sustainable Finance activities, and launching green mortgages in three new markets.

Research and development:
Our company has a four-year partnership with a leading research institution covering long-term research on Climate Risk, advisory on shorter-term, internally focused projects to enhance Climate Risk capabilities, and training of our colleagues, Management Team, and Board.

instruction:
For a TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) expert, let's discuss how to effectively manage and communicate climate risks and opportunities within an organization. Here's how to address the initial query:

1. Evaluate the robustness of the organization's strategy in the face of various climate-related situations, including a 2°C or lower scenario.

In simpler terms, as a TCFD expert, I will guide you on how to effectively handle and present climate risks and prospects within your organization. Let's begin by tackling the first question:

1. Assess the adaptability of the organization's strategy under diverse climate-related circumstances, including a 2°C or lower scenario.
output:
Approach to scenario analysis:
Over recent years, we have progressively strengthened our scenario analysis capabilities and developed our infrastructure and capabilities to incorporate Climate Risk into data, modelling, and analysis. Our company's work to date, using current assumptions and proxies, indicates that our business is resilient to all scenarios explored by the Network of Central Banks and Supervisors for Greening the Financial System (NGFS) and International Energy Agency (IEA).
In 2021, our company recognized Sustainability as a core component of our strategy, elevating it to a pillar of our Group Strategy. In July 2022, we formalised this further and appointed our inaugural Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO), to help drive our sustainability agenda and bring together our existing Sustainable Finance, Sustainability Strategy, and Net Zero Programme Management, teams.
Scenarios used:
In 2022, our company engaged a third-party vendor to begin development of bespoke internal modelling capabilities to provide greater transparency. We assessed the impact on our corporate client portfolio based on three IEA scenarios and three Phase 2 scenarios from the NGFS. Our company also assessed the impact of sea-level rises under various Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Representative Concentration Pathways (RCP) scenarios to explore the Physical Risk impact on our residential mortgage portfolio over short and long-term time horizons for internal risk management purposes.
Impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on business strategy:
Our company is working to reduce our exposure to high carbon emitting activities and is supporting clients in these industries to transition to lower carbon technologies. Our sustainable finance priorities, including new emerging products such as sustainable deposits, carbon trading and ESG Advisory, and dedicated transition frameworks, are a robust response to transition risks in the short term, strengthening our resilience towards a 2°C or lower transition scenario.

instruction:
As an expert on the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, I will outline the approaches for incorporating extensive climate-related risk evaluations and strategic decision-making into corporate administration. The goal is to elevate the caliber and reach of financial reporting.

To respond to your query, I will first explain the methods employed by the organization for recognizing and evaluating climate-related risks. These processes may include:

1. Establishing a cross-functional team responsible for climate risk assessment and management.
2. Conducting a materiality assessment to identify climate-sensitive areas within the business.
3. Utilizing scenario analysis to evaluate potential climate-related risks and opportunities under various climate conditions.
4. Implementing a climate risk monitoring and reporting system.
5. Engaging with stakeholders, including investors, regulators, and industry experts, to gain insights and best practices.

By following these steps, the organization can effectively identify and assess climate-related risks and integrate them into its corporate governance structure.
output:
Processes for identifying and assessing risk:
To support the management and monitoring of Physical and Transition risks, our company continues to conduct case-level reviews for enhanced due diligence on high risks for our corporate clients. The toolkits are used to identify and assess:
- Physical Risk: current-day and longer-term time horizons (representative concentration pathway (RCP) scenarios 2.6, 4.5 and 8.5), for acute weather events (e.g. storms, floods or earthquakes) and chronic sea-level rise.
- Transition Risk: translates Orderly, Disorderly and ‘Hot-House’ world transition scenario variables from relevant sources to financial impact at a client level.

Further information on client-level assessments can be found on a generic page, and the limitations of our methodology can be found on a different generic page.

We define Climate Risk as the potential for financial loss and non-financial detriments arising from climate change and society’s response to it. Within this, we assess and define sub-risk types in the form of a climate risk taxonomy which includes:
- Physical Risk: Risk arising from increasing severity and frequency of climate and weather-related events.
- Transition Risk: Risks arising from the adjustment towards a carbon-neutral economy, which will require significant structural changes to the economy.

Existing and emerging regulatory requirements related to climate change:
Our company has established a process for tracking various Climate Risk-related regulatory developments and obligations set by both financial and non-financial service regulators at our organization and regional/country level. Roles and responsibilities for these regulatory requirements or enhancements are set out in our Climate Risk Policy. Regulatory requirements or enhancements needed are recorded through workplans across various teams. The workplans are coordinated and monitored through various working groups by having the relevant accountable executives participate in the relevant forums.

Characterising climate-related risks in the context of traditional banking industry risk categories:
Our company has identified seven Principal Risk Types (PRT) that are most materially impacted by potential climate risks and describe transmission channels for Climate Risk manifesting as financial and non-financial risk.

instruction:
As an expert in the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, I will offer a comprehensive guide on how to effectively assess and communicate climate-related risks and opportunities. I will focus on the significance of governance, strategic alignment, and risk management practices in this context.

To begin with, let me outline the methods your organization employs to manage climate-related risks.

1. Governance:
The first step is to establish a clear climate risk management framework. This includes setting up a governance structure that ensures climate risks are integrated into the overall risk management system. This could involve appointing a board member or a senior executive to oversee climate risk management.

2. Strategic Alignment:
The second step is to align your organization's strategy with the low-carbon economy. This may involve setting science-based targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, identifying opportunities in the green economy, and integrating climate considerations into your business strategy.

3. Risk Management Practices:
The third step is to implement robust risk management practices to address climate-related risks. This could include conducting climate risk assessments, implementing risk mitigation strategies, and monitoring and reporting on climate-related risks and opportunities.

By following these steps, your organization will be well-equipped to manage climate-related risks effectively and report on them in accordance with the TCFD framework.
output:
Processes for managing and mitigating risks:
We manage Climate Risk according to the characteristics of these Potential Risk Factors (PRTs) and are embedding climate-risk considerations into the relevant frameworks and processes. We also set risk appetites for each.
Our Climate Risk Appetite Statement (RAS) is approved annually by the Board and is supported by Board and Management Team level risk appetite metrics. These metrics cover Credit Risk, Reputational and Sustainability Risk, Traded Risk, and Country Risk.
We regularly review the scope and coverage of our risk appetite metrics for enhanced risk identification and management. Additional metrics to address our public targets across key sectors and a stress loss metric built on scenario outcomes have been identified and are being monitored for inclusion in risk appetite reporting.
We have toolkits to quantitatively measure climate-related Physical and Transition Risks to determine if they should be prioritized for risk management purposes.

The Board annually approves our Climate Risk Appetite Statement (RAS), which is supported by risk appetite metrics at the Board and Management Team levels. These metrics encompass Credit Risk, Reputational and Sustainability Risk, Traded Risk, and Country Risk.

instruction:
As an expert in the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, I will offer a comprehensive guide on how to efficiently assess and communicate climate-related risks and opportunities. I will focus on the significance of governance, strategic alignment, and risk management practices in this context.

To begin, let's discuss how the identification, assessment, and management of climate-related risks are incorporated into an organization's risk management framework as a whole.

First, it is essential to establish a clear understanding of climate-related risks and opportunities within the organization. This can be achieved through various methods, such as conducting a materiality assessment, engaging in scenario analysis, or utilizing climate risk disclosure frameworks like TCFD.

Next, climate-related risks should be integrated into the organization's risk management policy and procedures. This can involve setting up a climate risk management function, establishing risk appetite statements, and incorporating climate risks into the organization's risk assessment and mitigation processes.

Moreover, climate-related risks should be monitored and reported regularly to the organization's senior management and board of directors. This transparency and accountability help ensure that climate risks are being effectively managed and that the organization remains aligned with its strategic objectives.

In summary, the integration of climate-related risks into an organization's overall risk management framework is crucial for effective risk assessment and reporting. By following these steps, organizations can effectively evaluate and communicate their climate-related risks and opportunities, ensuring that they are well-positioned to address the challenges and opportunities presented by climate change.
output:
Integration into Enterprise Risk Management Framework:
Climate Risk is recognized in our company's Enterprise Risk Management Framework (ERMF) as an integrated risk type. It manifests through existing risk types and is managed in accordance with the impacted risk type frameworks. We manage Climate Risk based on the characteristics of these risk types and are incorporating climate-risk considerations into the relevant frameworks and processes for each. In 2022, our company has continued to integrate Climate Risk into existing risk management processes, focusing on identifying, assessing, and monitoring across risk types.

Our operations: Despite a 5 percent decrease in measured real estate, we reduced our Scope 1 and 2 emissions by over 42 percent to 49,434 tonnes during 2022. This was achieved through a 3 percent reduction in energy consumption to 177.3 GWh due to energy-efficient investments, as well as a 12 percent increase in renewable energy across our portfolio.

We accomplished this reduction in emissions through strategic energy-efficient investments and an increase in the use of renewable energy sources.

In our supply chain: In collaboration with an independent climate consultancy, we continued enhancing the precision of our methodology for estimating supplier emissions. The process for measuring Scope 3 upstream vendor emissions is being integrated into our annual reporting process and is anticipated to be carried out during the first quarter of each year based on the previous year’s vendor spend.

We recognize the importance of addressing emissions in our supply chain and are committed to working with our suppliers to reduce their carbon footprint.

Measuring our financed emissions: Assessing our exposure to high-carbon sectors is the foundation of our financed emission calculations. In 2022, we expanded upon our 2021 progress by baselining our emissions for five high-emitting sectors, namely Oil and gas, Power, Coal mining, Steel and other Metals and mining. We also included three additional transport sectors: Automotive manufacturers, Aviation, and Shipping.

Our financial investments in these sectors contribute to their overall carbon emissions, and we are committed to understanding and reducing our carbon impact through our investments.

Our company's Direct Operations:
Risk management in our organization involves all functions, including assessing risks related to financial and market performance, operational performance, emergency preparedness and response, environment, health and safety compliance, and regulatory impacts. We prioritize risks based on their impact on our business, employees, communities, and customers. Our Enterprise Risk Management program identifies, assesses, prioritizes, and manages key enterprise risks, with climate-related risks and opportunities being part of this process.

Our Finance, Internal Audit, Legal, and Investor Relations departments identify and assess business risks, financial risks, market risks, and environmental compliance risks. These risks are reviewed as part of financial disclosure requirements. In addition, departments such as Environment, Health and Safety, Corporate Sales and Marketing, Legal, Operations, and Investor Relations assess specific physical and transitional risks and opportunities due to climate change. We have evaluated potential physical climate change risks to major facilities, including sea level rise flooding, susceptibility to and preparation for high intensity storms, increased rainfall, drought, and water stress and availability. Both company-level and asset-level physical and transitional risks have been considered, as well as raw material sourcing issues and distribution channel impacts. We use a substantial amount as a threshold for substantive financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.

Our company uses a materiality assessment to review and prioritize sustainability topics, including corporate governance, products, environmental protection (including climate change), social responsibility, and economic performance. Our top management is interviewed to discuss which aspects are most relevant for our company's future success, and external stakeholders are consulted to understand their perspectives. The results from the materiality assessment guide us toward which areas to focus on in the future. Our Environment, Health & Safety department is responsible for maintaining our ISO 14001 certifications. Our ISO 14001 environmental management systems involve assessing environmental impacts of our manufacturing operations, including those impacted by climate change. Significant impacts for each site covered under an ISO 14001 certification are determined using a ranking system.

We have established corporate-wide goals to manage climate-related risks. Our sustainability goals include a climate change-related target of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions by 50% by 2030 relative to a base year. We also have a long-term goal of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions in line with the Paris Agreement to further reduce our climate impact and support limiting warming to 1.5°C and transitioning to a net-zero carbon economy.

As we rely on global suppliers for raw materials, their locations may be subject to various supply constraints, including those due to climate change. In instances where our company depends on a limited number of suppliers for certain raw materials, components, services, and equipment used in the manufacturing of our products, climate change-related risks could affect us. For example, chronic drought or flooding could increase instability in regions of the world that supply critical raw materials, causing business interruption. We use a substantial amount as a threshold for substantive financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.

Our company assesses upstream risks by calculating our upstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Procurement department manages both physical and transitional risks and opportunities in our supply chain. Our dedicated staff, Supplier Code of Conduct, Purchase Order Terms and Conditions, and Responsible Minerals Sourcing Policy help us manage potential supply chain risks, including those associated with climate change. Where possible, we seek to obtain goods and services from local suppliers in the locations where we conduct business, which helps reduce our risk of business interruptions when climate-related issues may arise and lowers transportation emission impacts.

During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the potential impact of climate change on our business downstream. We believe climate change presents a potential opportunity for us because our products are specifically designed to reduce energy consumption and GHG emissions compared to incumbent technologies. However, climate-related events could cause delays in product distribution, resulting in commercial risks associated with delivering our products in a timely manner. We use a substantial amount as a threshold for substantive financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.

Our company assesses downstream risks by calculating our downstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Corporate Sales and Marketing department manages our climate-related transitional risks and opportunities, including those related to our product sales, our reputation, market projections, and consumer preferences. We assess market trends and technology advancements to suggest what our business focus should be. For example, we have shifted our strategic focus toward our semiconductor business due to the anticipated increased adoption of energy-efficient technologies that use our products (e.g., renewable energy, electric vehicles).

6. Reporting: Communicating transparently with stakeholders about the organization's climate risk management processes and outcomes.

By integrating climate risks into their organizational strategy, companies can better understand and address the potential financial, operational, and reputational impacts of a changing climate. 1. What is the role of the board in governance?

The board of directors plays a pivotal role in setting the strategic direction of the organization and overseeing its risk management framework. They establish the company's risk appetite and ensure that risk management is integrated into the organization's overall strategy and operations. The board also monitors the implementation of risk management policies and practices, and holds senior management accountable for their risk management decisions.

2. How does the board ensure effective risk management?

The board ensures effective risk management by establishing a risk management framework that aligns with the organization's strategic objectives and risk appetite. This includes setting clear roles and responsibilities for risk management, providing adequate resources, and ensuring that risk management is integrated into the organization's decision-making processes. The board also engages with senior management to review and challenge their risk assessments and risk management strategies, and maintains an oversight function to monitor the implementation of risk management policies and practices.

Board-level involvement in risk management is crucial for effective risk management and ensuring that the organization's risk profile aligns with its strategic objectives and risk appetite. The board should be informed about the organization's risk management framework, including its risk identification, assessment, and mitigation processes. The board should also be involved in the approval of significant risk-taking activities and the establishment of risk limits. Additionally, the board should ensure that there is a culture of risk awareness and risk management throughout the organization, and that risk management is integrated into the organization's decision-making processes.

instruction:
In light of your knowledge in TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures), please address the following inquiries:

1. How do organizations effectively manage risks and seize opportunities associated with climate change?
output:
Our company does not see any substantial transitional or physical risks from climate change that have a material impact on us, but rather view the transition toward a low carbon economy as an opportunity. Climate change and its mitigation are significant issues for our stakeholders. We enable our customers to lower their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by providing low carbon and energy-efficient products, solutions, and services. Our Environmental Portfolio (EP) helps our customers to mitigate their CO2 footprint, reduce energy costs, and improve profitability through higher productivity. In fiscal 2020, we managed to reduce 150 million metric tons of CO2 at customer sites. Our business SI has been established with a priority focus on decentralization, decarbonization, and energy efficiency in buildings and cities. SI strategy addresses the ongoing challenges and seizes the opportunities of new technologies around the grid edge with products and solutions for decentralized energy systems, photovoltaic inverters, energy storage, smart and sustainable buildings, and electro mobility, enabled by digitalization.

We are committed to becoming carbon neutral by 2030. In this year, we managed to halve our emissions compared to a benchmark year. Among other benefits, this program reduces potential carbon taxational risk on our operations. Through our dedicated decarbonization program within the supply chain, we also reduce this risk upstream.

With respect to potential physical risks, we continuously evaluate and monitor changes in climate parameters based on global studies, weather statistics, and trends based on international experience of insurance companies. We do not consider those risks to lead to substantive changes in operations, revenue, or expense as they allow for mitigation. In addition, we perform local risk assessments and develop protection concepts if needed. Furthermore, our insurance department provides natural hazard risks analysis for each new building project that drives the selection process for new site areas and influences technical, organizational, and physical protection measures.

We evaluate 80% of our insured value with respect to fire safety but also natural catastrophes, such as storms, floods, hurricanes, on a yearly basis. The analysis revealed that major sites were exposed. We see floods exposure mainly in Europe, whereas some sites in other countries are exposed to storms or hurricanes. For these identified sites, a more detailed risk analysis was performed, and results were provided to our insurer to adjust payment conditions. In addition, we provided measures to be taken by the identified sites, such as installation of flood barriers, thickening of roofs. The requirements for risk mitigation measures are continuously enhanced and consider risk changes.

Our company's Water Strategy is complementary to the physical risk assessment process. Based on our global binding EHS regulation, every environmentally relevant site must perform a risk assessment. This includes the evaluation of water-related climate change risks, such as their water stress level, exposure to flooding, droughts, and general water availability. For this assessment, we use Aqueduct (WRI) and IPCC data to predict changes in precipitation. This assessment is verified by our internal tool with each site responsible for performing a bottom-up analysis. In fiscal 2020, we had analyzed 97% of locations.

One example for an acute physical risk could be from drought in water-stressed areas. One of our sites has established a comprehensive water management system with active collection of rainwater during the monsoon, which is fed back into the ground to increase necessary groundwater level during the dry season instead of letting it run off through sewers. In addition, the site benefits, as it is more independent from the public water supply.

Natural disasters could potentially interrupt our supply chain. However, supply chain risks are low due to our diversified supplier base, worldwide operations, and a limited number of our company's facilities concentrated in any particular region, including those regions more likely to be affected by natural disasters. We analyze potential supply chain disruptions both within our supplier selection and qualification process as well as in the phase of continuous supply chain operations. Based on external real-time data from service provider risk methods, which indicates risk alerts in any region worldwide, our businesses are mitigating upcoming supply chain risks to ensure flawless deliveries to our customers. We preventively manage several risk cases to ensure the resilience of our supply chain during major crises.

1. Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) Processes:

ERM is a systematic approach that enables organizations to identify, assess, and prioritize risks, and coordinate their responses to mitigate, monitor, and control the risks. Climate-related risks, such as physical risks (e.g., extreme weather events) and transition risks (e.g., regulatory changes), are increasingly becoming a critical component of ERM.

To enhance transparency in ERM processes related to climate risks, organizations can:

a. Establish a clear climate risk management policy and integrate it into the overall risk management framework.
b. Identify, assess, and prioritize climate risks using a risk assessment methodology.
c. Develop and implement strategies to mitigate, monitor, and control climate risks.
d. Establish a process for reporting and disclosing climate risks to stakeholders, including investors, regulators, and the public.
e. Continuously monitor and review the effectiveness of climate risk management processes and adjust as necessary.

By following these steps, organizations can demonstrate their commitment to addressing climate risks and provide greater transparency to stakeholders.

Our internal auditors regularly assess the adequacy and effectiveness of our risk management, and any deficiencies can be addressed through appropriate measures.

Our risk management approach is comprehensive, interactive, and management-oriented, and is integrated into our organization. It addresses both risks and opportunities. Our approach is based on globally accepted standards, such as the COSO Standard and ISO 31000, and is adapted to our company's requirements. The frameworks connect our risk management process with our financial reporting process and internal control system.

The bottom-up identification and prioritization process is supplemented by workshops with the respective management of our organizational units. The top-down element ensures that potential new risks and opportunities are discussed at different management levels and are included in the subsequent reporting process, if found to be relevant.

Reported risks and opportunities are analyzed for potential cumulative effects and are aggregated within and for each of the organizational units mentioned. Responsibilities are assigned for all relevant risks and opportunities, with the level of responsibility depending on the significance of the respective risk or opportunity. For each risk or opportunity, responsibility involves the development, initiation, and monitoring of appropriate response measures corresponding to the chosen response strategy. output:

Our internal auditors regularly review the adequacy and effectiveness of our risk management. If deficiencies are detected, appropriate measures can be adopted for their elimination. This coordination of processes and procedures is intended to help ensure that the Managing Board and the Supervisory Board are fully informed about significant risks in a timely manner.

Our risk management approach is comprehensive, interactive, and management-oriented, integrated into the organization, and addresses both risks and opportunities. It is based on globally accepted standards, such as the COSO Standard and ISO Standard 31000, and is adapted to our requirements. The frameworks connect the risk management process with our financial reporting process and internal control system. They consider our strategy, the efficiency and effectiveness of our business operations, the reliability of our financial reporting, and compliance with relevant laws and regulations to be equally important.

Our risk management process aims for early identification and evaluation of risks and opportunities that could materially affect the achievement of our strategic, operational, financial, and compliance objectives. The time horizon is typically three years, and we take a net risk approach, addressing risks and opportunities remaining after the execution of existing control measures. Relevant risks and opportunities are identified in a structured way, combining elements of both top-down and bottom-up approaches. Reporting generally follows a quarterly cycle, with an ad-hoc reporting process to escalate critical issues in a timely manner.

The top-down element ensures that potential new risks and opportunities are discussed at different management levels and are included in the subsequent reporting process, if found to be relevant.

Reported risks and opportunities are analyzed regarding potential cumulative effects and are aggregated within and for each of the organizational units mentioned above. Responsibilities are assigned for all relevant risks and opportunities, with the hierarchical level of responsibility depending on the significance of the respective risk or opportunity. In a first step, assuming responsibility for a specific risk or opportunity involves choosing one of our general response strategies. Our general response strategies with respect to risks are avoidance, transfer, reduction, or acceptance of the relevant risk. Our general response strategy with respect to opportunities is to "seize" the relevant opportunity. In a second step, responsibility for a risk or opportunity also involves the development, initiation, and monitoring of appropriate response measures corresponding to the chosen response strategy. These response measures have to be specifically tailored to allow for effective risk management.

We have developed a variety of response measures with different characteristics. For example, we mitigate the risk of fluctuations in currency and interest rates by engaging in hedging activities. Regarding our projects, systematic and comprehensive project management with standardized project milestones, including provisional acceptances during project execution and complemented by clearly defined approval processes, assists us in identifying and responding to project risks at an early stage, even before the bidding phase. Furthermore, we maintain appropriate insurance levels for potential cases of damage and liability risks to reduce our exposure to such risks and to avoid or minimize potential losses.

We address the risk of fluctuation in economic activity and customer demand by closely monitoring macroeconomic conditions and developments in relevant industries and adjusting capacity and implementing cost-reduction measures in a timely and consistent manner if they are deemed necessary.

Our company constantly checks information from reputable sources, such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the American and European Centers for Disease Control, and the German Robert Koch Institute, to identify epidemic or pandemic risks and related mitigation actions as early as possible.

Using your extensive knowledge of the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, let's delve into the essential elements of risk management within an organization and explore how these aspects intersect with governance and strategy to foster a robust response to climate change. I'll address the following questions:

1. A clear description of the organization's procedures for recognizing and evaluating climate change risks.

Organizations employ various processes to identify and assess climate change risks. These processes may include:

- Establishing a risk management function or team dedicated to climate change risks.
- Conducting regular climate risk assessments, which may involve scenario analysis, stress testing, and vulnerability assessments.
- Integrating climate change risks into existing risk management frameworks, such as enterprise risk management (ERM) or operational risk management (ORM).
- Engaging external experts, such as consultants, academics, and industry associations, to provide additional insights and expertise.

By implementing these processes, organizations can gain a better understanding of their climate change risks and develop strategies to manage and mitigate them effectively. This proactive approach not only helps organizations adapt to the physical and transitional risks associated with climate change but also enhances their overall resilience and sustainability.

2. The role of governance in managing climate change risks and ensuring effective risk disclosure.

Governance plays a crucial role in managing climate change risks and ensuring effective risk disclosure. Effective governance structures enable organizations to:

- Establish clear lines of responsibility for climate change risks and their management.
- Implement policies and procedures that promote transparency and accountability in climate risk reporting.
- Encourage a culture of risk awareness and proactive risk management.
- Ensure that climate change risks are integrated into the organization's overall risk management framework.

By fostering a strong governance framework, organizations can effectively manage climate change risks and provide accurate and comprehensive disclosures to stakeholders, as required by the TCFD framework.

3. The importance of strategy in addressing climate change risks and fostering a resilient approach.

Strategy plays a vital role in addressing climate change risks and fostering a resilient approach. Effective strategies enable organizations to:

- Identify and prioritize climate change risks based on their potential impact on the organization's operations, assets, and reputation.
- Develop and implement plans to manage and mitigate these risks, such as transitioning to low-carbon business models, investing in renewable energy, and improving energy efficiency.
- Engage stakeholders, including investors, regulators, and industry associations, to collaborate on climate change initiatives and share best practices.

By adopting a proactive and strategic approach to climate change risks, organizations can not only reduce their vulnerability to the physical and transitional risks associated with climate change but also position themselves as leaders in the transition to a low-carbon economy.

instruction:
As an expert on the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, I will outline the approaches for incorporating extensive climate-related risk evaluations and strategic planning into corporate governance, with the objective of improving the depth and reach of financial reporting. In response to your query, here is a description of the methods employed by the organization to manage climate change risks:

1. Identification and assessment of climate-related risks: The organization conducts a thorough analysis of its operations, supply chain, and business environment to identify and evaluate climate-related risks. This includes physical risks, such as extreme weather events, and transition risks, such as regulatory changes and technological advancements.

2. Risk prioritization and mitigation: Based on the results of the risk assessment, the organization prioritizes risks and implements measures to mitigate them. This may involve the adoption of new technologies, the development of contingency plans, or the establishment of partnerships and collaborations.

3. Integration of climate-related risks into decision-making: Climate-related risks are integrated into the organization's decision-making processes, from strategic planning to day-to-day operations. This ensures that the organization is well-positioned to respond to climate-related challenges and opportunities.

4. Monitoring and reporting: The organization continuously monitors and reports on its climate-related risks and the effectiveness of its risk management strategies. This information is disclosed in accordance with the TCFD framework, providing stakeholders with a clear understanding of the organization's climate-related risks and its approach to managing them.
output: Our company's climate change risk management is an essential component of our multi-tier risk management system. Climate change risks are identified, analyzed, and assessed by risk owners (heads of business lines and structural units) in collaboration with our risk control division. Risks are identified based on a classification system. This system conforms to the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).

output:
Process, frequency, and responsibility – Our Board assumes overall accountability for our company's ESG strategy, guiding executive management in its creation, execution, and reporting. It has strengthened its oversight of ESG matters, introducing a dedicated agenda item for 2022. Sub-committee accountability, processes, and frequency – Our Group Risk Committee (‘GRC’) ensures delivery plans to establish strong climate risk management capabilities. Our Group Chairman and our CEO held regular meetings with government officials worldwide to maintain robust international relationships. instruction:
Based on your profound knowledge of the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, I will outline the optimal practices for amplifying transparency and responsibility in climate-related financial reporting. I will primarily concentrate on governance structures and strategic planning to tackle environmental challenges.

Regarding your inquiry, I will first address the role of management in evaluating and managing climate-related risks and prospects.

Management plays a pivotal role in identifying, assessing, and managing climate-related risks and opportunities. They are responsible for integrating climate considerations into their overall risk management framework and strategic planning processes. This integration ensures that the organization is well-positioned to seize opportunities and mitigate risks associated with climate-related issues.

Moreover, management should establish clear lines of responsibility for climate-related risks and opportunities within the organization. This may involve designating a senior executive or a specialized team to oversee climate-related matters. Additionally, they should ensure that climate-related risks and opportunities are adequately reflected in the organization's financial statements and disclosures.

Furthermore, management should engage with stakeholders, including investors, regulators, and industry groups, to foster a better understanding of climate-related risks and opportunities and to promote transparency and accountability in climate reporting.

In summary, management's role in assessing and managing climate-related risks and opportunities is crucial for enhancing transparency and accountability in climate-related financial disclosures. By integrating climate considerations into their risk management framework and strategic planning processes, establishing clear lines of responsibility, and engaging with stakeholders, organizations can effectively address environmental challenges and provide investors with valuable information for informed decision-making.

instruction:
Based on your comprehensive understanding of the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD), let's explore how a well-integrated strategy can help address climate-related risks and opportunities for an organization.

First, it's essential to acknowledge the climate-related risks and prospects that the business has recognized over various time horizons.

1. In the short term, what climate-related threats and opportunities have been identified?
2. What climate-related risks and opportunities does the organization anticipate in the medium term?
3. And, finally, which climate-related risks and opportunities does the business foresee in the long term?

By integrating climate considerations into the organization's strategy, the company can effectively manage these risks and seize opportunities, ensuring a more resilient and sustainable future.
output:
Processes used to determine material risks and opportunities: Our company has developed capabilities to execute climate stress testing and scenario analysis to improve our understanding of risk exposures for risk management and business decision making. Due to challenges in data sourcing and processes, there have been impacts on certain climate disclosures.

We have established methods to assess climate risks and uncover opportunities. Climate scenario analysis serves as a risk assessment tool, shedding light on the long-term consequences of transition and physical risks across our corporate and retail banking portfolios, as well as our own operations. Our sustainable finance strategy supports sustainable infrastructure and energy systems, promotes decarbonisation efforts across the real economy, and enhances investor capital through sustainable investment.

Our goal is to reach net zero in our financed emissions by 2050 and in our own operations and supply chain by 2030. We aim to facilitate and provide $750bn to $1tn of sustainable finance and investment for our customers in their transition to net zero and a sustainable future.

Our assessment of climate risks covers three distinct time periods: short term (up to 2025), medium term (2026 to 2035), and long term (2036 to 2050). Transition or physical climate-related issues are identified using enhanced questionnaires and scoring tools.

We support our customers in their transition through our sustainable finance and investment strategy. Our sustainable finance data dictionary includes a detailed definition of contributing activities.

Certain perils, such as coastal, river, and surface water flooding, may lead to potential credit losses in our retail portfolio. Approximately 20% of our financed properties are located in London, and most are protected by various flood protection measures.

We have identified six key sectors with the highest exposure to climate transition risk: automotive, chemicals, construction and building materials, metals and mining, oil and gas, and power and utilities. We have continued to enhance our identification and assessment of climate risk within our retail mortgage portfolio, with increased investments in physical risk data and improvements to our internal risk assessment capabilities and models.

Opportunities include sustainable finance, sustainable investment, and sustainable infrastructure. For a detailed breakdown of our sustainable finance progress by geography, see the ESG Data Pack.

We report our exposure to high transition risk sectors in our wholesale portfolio. Since 2020, we have expanded the questionnaire to include our largest customers in the next highest climate transition risk sectors: agriculture, industrials, real estate, and transportation.

As a result of climate scenario analysis, our largest and most impacted sectors – power and utilities, construction and building materials, and chemicals – are subject to increased levels of transition risks. Our asset management division is increasingly considering both physical and transition risks and integrating ESG and climate analysis into the investment decision-making process.

Transition to net zero represents one of our strategic pillars. We aim to be net zero in our operations and supply chain by 2030 and in our financed emissions by 2050. Scenario analysis supports our strategy by assessing our position under a range of climate scenarios and helping us plan for the future and meet growing regulatory requirements.

We continue to develop our climate scenario analysis exercises to gain a more comprehensive understanding of climate headwinds, risks, and opportunities that will support our strategic planning and actions. We do not currently fully disclose the impacts of climate-related issues on financial planning, particularly the impact on financial performance and financial position. We expect to further enhance our disclosure and processes in relation to acquisitions/divestments in the medium term.

Climate change poses a physical risk to the buildings we occupy as an organization, including offices, retail branches, and data centers. We use stress testing to evaluate the potential impact to our owned or leased premises. Our scenario stress test, conducted in 2022, analyzed how seven different climate change-related hazards could impact 500 of our critical and important buildings.

Our Climate Solutions Partnership is a philanthropic initiative that aims to identify and remove barriers to scale for climate change solutions. We support start-up companies developing carbon-cutting technologies, nature-based solutions, renewable energy initiatives in Asia, and the WWF-led Asia Sustainable Palm Oil Links programme.

During Board meetings, we balance discussions on the company's performance, emerging risks, and duties to shareholders while remaining conscious of responsibilities to support communities and help customers. In 2022, the Board approved an update to the thermal coal phase-out policy and the publication of an updated energy policy. We have committed to publishing our own climate transition plan in 2023.

output:

Our company's approach to embedding climate considerations into scenario analysis:
Scenario analysis is a crucial tool for our company, as it helps us assess our position under various climate scenarios, expand our awareness of climate change, plan for the future, and comply with growing regulatory requirements. In 2022, we carried out our initial in-house climate scenario analysis exercise, employing four scenarios to represent the spectrum of potential climate outcomes. This analysis took into account the key regions where we operate and evaluated the impact on our balance sheet between the 2022 and 2050 timeframe.

Key performance drivers and their consideration:
Climate scenario analysis allows us to model the potential impact of different climate pathways on our customer base and investment portfolios, particularly in terms of credit losses. Under the Current Commitments scenario, we anticipate moderate levels of losses associated with transition risks. Government policies and scenario assumptions:

Adaptation and evolution of our strategies:
The nature of the scenarios, our evolving capabilities, and the limitations of the analysis result in indicative outcomes of climate change headwinds, although they do not represent a direct forecast. Developments in climate science, data, methodology, and scenario analysis techniques will help us refine our approach further. As a result, our perspective on risk is expected to evolve over time.

Our company's intentions:
We plan to continue enhancing our climate scenario analysis capabilities and utilize the results for decision-making, particularly in relation to strategy, by leveraging the range of scenario analysis outcomes to shape our strategy across business and regions. Currently, we do not fully disclose the impacts of transition and physical risk quantitatively due to transitional challenges, including data limitations and evolving science and methodologies.

In simpler terms, how does the organization effectively incorporate climate-related risk management into its overall risk management strategy?

First and foremost, it is crucial for an organization to establish a clear understanding of climate-related risks and their potential impact on its operations, assets, and financial performance. This understanding is typically gained through a systematic process of risk identification, assessment, and prioritization.

Once identified, climate-related risks should be integrated into the organization's risk management framework. This can be achieved through various means, such as:

- Incorporating climate-related risks into the organization's risk appetite statement, which sets out the level and type of risk that the organization is willing to accept.
- Ensuring that climate-related risks are considered in the context of the organization's risk assessment and mitigation processes, such as stress testing and scenario analysis.
- Establishing a climate risk management function or team to oversee the identification, assessment, and mitigation of climate-related risks.
- Integrating climate-related risks into the organization's strategic planning process, ensuring that climate-related risks and opportunities are considered in the context of the organization's long-term business strategy.

By integrating climate-related risks into its overall risk management strategy, an organization can more effectively manage these risks and minimize their potential impact on its operations, assets, and financial performance. This, in turn, can help the organization better prepare for and respond to the physical and transitional risks associated with climate change.

This promotes clear lines of accountability across our investment and operations teams, oversight functions such as Risk and Assurance, and Advisory. Organizations face increasing pressure to disclose climate-related information to stakeholders, investors, and regulatory bodies. To ensure detailed, accurate, and actionable climate-related disclosures, advanced methodologies include the following:

1. Integration of climate-related risks and opportunities into the organization's overall risk management framework.
2. Implementation of climate scenario analysis to assess the potential financial impact of various climate-related risks and opportunities on the organization's businesses, strategy, and financial planning.
3. Utilization of climate-related key performance indicators (KPIs) and targets to measure and report progress towards climate-related goals.
4. Collaboration with external experts, such as climate scientists and consultants, to gain a better understanding of climate-related risks and opportunities and to develop appropriate disclosure strategies.

Regarding the first question, it is crucial for organizations to understand the impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on their businesses, strategy, and financial planning. Climate-related risks can manifest in various forms, such as physical risks (e.g., extreme weather events, sea-level rise, and natural disasters) and transition risks (e.g., regulatory changes, technological advancements, and shifts in market preferences).

Climate-related opportunities can include the development and implementation of innovative climate-related solutions, such as renewable energy projects, energy efficiency initiatives, and circular economy business models. Organizations that effectively manage climate-related risks and seize climate-related opportunities can gain a competitive advantage and contribute to a more sustainable future.

Therefore, it is essential for organizations to integrate climate-related risks and opportunities into their overall risk management framework, assess their potential financial impact through climate scenario analysis, and report their progress towards climate-related goals using climate-related KPIs and targets. By doing so, organizations can ensure detailed, accurate, and actionable climate-related disclosures that meet the requirements of the TCFD and provide valuable information to stakeholders, investors, and regulatory bodies.

Physical risks mainly focus on growing electricity costs due to chronic climate changes, such as rising temperatures. Costs related to combating drought include expenses for building water reclamation systems, using reclaimed water, and purchasing backup water sources. For acute climate change disasters like floods and strong winds, we have already designed prevention systems into our facilities and will not be calculating their financial impact.

Our company has also estimated the cost of reputation damage from failing to meet net zero emission targets. However, there is no globally recognized approach to estimate such financial impact. The financial impact of a 1% revenue reduction was a consensus reached by experts after discussions and assessments. The estimated financial impact from climate opportunities includes reduced costs from increased energy and water use efficiency and diverse water sources, as well as additional income from providing low-carbon products and services such as advanced manufacturing processes, Power Management ICs (PMICs), and ultralow power (ULP) ICs.

Analysis results indicate that developing low-carbon products and services presents the greatest opportunity for positive financial impacts, as demands for such products continue to grow.

With your knowledge of TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures), let me suggest the essential actions an organization should undertake to enhance its climate disclosures. Respond to the subsequent inquiries:

1. Evaluate the robustness of your organization's strategy in the face of various climate-related situations, including a 2°C or less scenario.

(Note: The text has been rephrased while preserving the original meaning and elements. The length remains similar.)
output:
1. In compliance with TCFD recommendations, our company has evaluated the impact of various greenhouse gas (GHG) emission controls on our operations and the supply chain for certain transition and physical risks. We have considered the outcomes when determining the resiliency of strategies and have also referred to the latest physical science basis, published by the International Energy Agency (IEA) and Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), to develop our own climate scenarios. In addition, we have also included potential growth in carbon emissions from expanding our business and new facilities as well as existing carbon reduction actions into general evaluations to analyze the potential financial impacts of climate risks. In the past, we evaluated climate risks solely using the worst-case scenario, but the future of climate change is highly unpredictable. As such, we have opted to evaluate climate risks across several scenarios this year to help map out and communicate operations strategies internally and give comprehensive insights into climate trends over the mid-to-long term.

2. Climate Scenario Selection
In terms of transition risks, there is now a global consensus that carbon pricing schemes are a necessary policy to achieve net zero emissions. We referenced a commonly used report, the World Energy Outlook 2022 (WEO), and selected the Net-Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario (NZE) and Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS) to conduct climate scenario analysis on future carbon pricing. The resulting carbon pricing then serves as the basis for us to evaluate the impacts of carbon pricing schemes on our locations in different countries.

3. In terms of physical risks, we referenced the Sixth Assessment Report (AR6) published by IPCC in 2021 and the latest Global Climate Model (GCM) to estimate long-term climate changes in the future. We also adopted a scenario to derive GHG emissions under different social and economic landscapes. Our impact analysis on physical risks covers climate change evaluations across every region of the globe and provides detailed impact analysis to our locations and suppliers around the world through downscaling analysis.

instruction:
Based on your profound knowledge of the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, I will outline the optimal practices for improving transparency and accountability in climate-related financial reports. I will concentrate on governance structures and strategic planning to tackle environmental challenges.

Regarding your inquiry, I will address the first question:

1. Detail the organization’s procedures for recognizing and evaluating climate-related risks:

A. Establish a clear risk identification and assessment process: This may involve the creation of a cross-functional team responsible for climate risk management. The team should consist of representatives from various departments, including risk management, legal, sustainability, and finance.

B. Utilize a systematic approach to climate risk assessment: This may include the use of climate scenario analysis, stress testing, and other quantitative and qualitative methods to evaluate the potential impact of climate-related risks on the organization’s financial performance.

C. Integrate climate risk into the organization’s overall risk management framework: Climate risk should be treated as a material risk, and its implications should be considered in the context of the organization’s overall risk management strategy.

D. Regularly review and update the organization’s climate risk assessment: The assessment should be reviewed and updated on a regular basis to reflect changing climate conditions and emerging risks.

E. Communicate climate risks effectively: The organization should clearly and effectively communicate climate risks to stakeholders, including investors, regulators, and the public. This may involve the use of standardized reporting frameworks, such as the TCFD framework, to ensure consistency and comparability.

Our company will identify and address risks and opportunities, implement responses, and monitor performance and outcomes. Financial impact analysis will be conducted for material risks and opportunities. Related business divisions will host group discussions to identify risks and opportunities that require attention. Risks and opportunities will be filtered based on external trends and internal operational changes.

The Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) impact evaluation framework will be used to calculate probability and impact. Note that impact includes impact on our business, finance, operations, employee safety, and reputation, and can be categorized into five levels - high, medium-high, medium, medium-low, and low - based on the level of impact. Probability is calculated based on incidence rate and time, and can be categorized into five levels as well - almost certain, very likely, likely, unlikely, and very unlikely.

We will note and rank risks and opportunities. Material risks and opportunities will be identified and developed into a risk and opportunity matrix. Response measures and financial impacts of material issues will be formulated and reviewed.

instruction:
With my TCFD expertise, I will outline the approach to crafting comprehensive disclosures concerning climate-related objectives and measurements. Respond to the following inquiries:

1. Provide a detailed account of the organization's procedures for addressing climate-related risks.

To structure effective disclosures on climate-related targets and metrics, adhere to the TCFD framework. Begin by addressing the following questions:

1. Describe the organization’s processes for managing climate-related risks:

a. Identify: Recognize and prioritize climate-related risks and opportunities that could materially impact the organization's business, strategy, and financial performance.

b. Assess: Evaluate the likelihood and potential impact of these risks and opportunities, considering both short-term and long-term implications.

c. Mitigate: Implement strategies to reduce the likelihood and impact of identified climate-related risks. Monitor and report on the effectiveness of these strategies.

d. Disclose: Communicate the organization's approach to managing climate-related risks and opportunities, including the rationale for any significant judgments or estimates.

By following this approach, organizations can provide transparent and consistent disclosures that enable stakeholders to understand the potential financial impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on the organization's business.
output: Our company manages key climate-related risks and opportunities through a holistic and balanced approach. The Audit and Risk Committee, authorized by the Board of Directors, oversees our risk management framework and risk profile, ensuring key risks are within the acceptable risk appetite. At the management level, the Risk Management Division collaborates with business teams and various committees, including the Risk Management Steering Committee, Risk Management Executive Council, and Risk Management Taskforces. This collaboration applies our risk management framework to assess and mitigate climate-related risks adequately. These risks include, but are not limited to, net zero emission challenges, reputation impact, business interruptions from water/energy shortages or disruptions, and natural disasters threatening our operations and supply chain. Annually, the Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) Division reports assessment results, financial impacts, and countermeasures against climate-related risks and opportunities to the ESG Committee. The Risk Management Division updates the Audit and Risk Committee on the assessment of climate risks and the mitigation plan taken.

instruction:
To serve as a TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) authoritative body, it is essential to address the following inquiries:

1. Elucidate the manner in which the organization integrates procedures for recognizing, evaluating, and addressing climate-related risks into its comprehensive risk management framework.
output:
Our company's integration of climate-related risk management into the risk management framework is structured through the Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) framework. This process is guided by the Audit and Risk Committee. By incorporating climate-related risks into our overall risk management, we ensure that they are identified, assessed, and managed in line with our strategic objectives and risk appetite. The ERM framework is applied organization-wide by the Risk Management Division in collaboration with various business teams and specialized committees. This systematic approach ensures a comprehensive assessment of risks and the implementation of appropriate mitigation strategies. The annual reporting mechanism, which is handled by the ESH Division to the ESG Committee, and subsequent updates to the Audit and Risk Committee, further integrates climate risk management with corporate governance. This holistic and embedded approach to climate risk management is a key component of our overall risk management and strategic planning processes.

1. Reveal the specific metrics employed by the organization to evaluate climate-related risks and prospects in accordance with its strategic objectives and risk management protocols.
output: Our company, as a technology provider in a dedicated IC foundry, is deeply conscious of our responsibilities to the communities where we operate and the global environment. In addition to establishing mid and long-term goals for our four major management initiatives, we conduct annual reviews and make rolling adjustments based on external factors and trends, with the objective of minimizing climate impacts through management by objectives and ensuring business continuity. In response to the increasing carbon costs associated with global low-carbon transitions, we have initiated an internal carbon pricing scheme. This scheme takes into account various factors such as regulations, fines, market pricing, and costs of carbon reduction. This carbon pricing scheme incorporates carbon costs into the impact valuations of our daily reduction measures and influences our investment decisions regarding new facilities. For instance, in 2022, we implemented 684 energy conservation measures across eight categories under our energy conservation program, saving approximately 700 GWh in energy that year. Evaluations using our internal carbon pricing scheme suggest that the potential external carbon costs from carbon emission reductions amount to around NT$530 million.

instruction:
With your expertise in TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures), let's delve into strategic approaches for clear and meaningful climate-related disclosures. Respond to the subsequent queries:

1. Disclose the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions encompassed in Scope 1, Scope 2, and, if necessary, Scope 3, alongside the associated risks.

(Note: The TCFD framework outlines three scopes of GHG emissions: Scope 1 refers to direct emissions from sources that are owned or controlled by the reporting entity; Scope 2 refers to indirect emissions from the generation of purchased energy; and Scope 3 refers to all other indirect emissions, such as those from the supply chain and transportation of goods.)
output: Our company is committed to reaching net zero emissions. Every year, we evaluate our progress in carbon reduction by conducting an annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions inventory and formulating carbon reduction strategies. In 2022, our direct emissions from processes (Scope 1) accounted for 11% and were primarily from fluorinated gases and nitrous oxide. Indirect GHG emissions from purchased energy (Scope 2) accounted for 50%. Indirect GHG emissions from the value chain (Scope 3) accounted for 39%. These indirect emissions were primarily from producing raw materials, energy-related activities in the upstream, and transportation.

output: Our company works with upstream suppliers, design ecosystem partners, and downstream businesses to consider the full product lifecycle and take meaningful action to decrease the carbon footprint of our offerings. With our innovative leading semiconductor process technologies, we enable our customers to create more advanced, energy-efficient, and eco-friendly products. Examples of our green products include ultra-low power and low operating voltage wearable devices, Internet of Things chips, low-power phone chips, LED driver chips for backlight systems in flat panel displays, LED driver chips for indoor and outdoor solid-state lighting, low standby power AC/DC transformer chips certified by Energy Star, high-performance brushless DC motor chips, electric vehicle chips, and low-power server chips. Chips manufactured using our high-performance and energy-efficient technologies can support infrastructure for sustainable cities, energy-efficient transportation, smart grids, and energy-efficient servers and data centers. Our company is dedicated to reducing our supply chain's impact on climate change through our core strategies of developing and purchasing energy-efficient green tools and implementing low-carbon supply chain management. We will continue to optimize our management and actions based on our Net Zero Emissions goal and carbon emissions hotspot analysis on the supply chain, helping suppliers allocate resources efficiently, strengthen carbon reduction capabilities, and build a green, low-carbon supply chain.
